ratings.question_text: Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: N/A
Virtual guests and presentations were incorporated well!!

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I developed reading and comprehension skills as well as my ability to think critically and discuss with my peers.
understanding the complexity of our relationship with food, how history, heritage, and privilege have lasting impacts on individuals
I  gained a much deeper understanding of the way that food and WGSS topics intersect, and it encouraged me to be more critical of the histories of food and food service.

Id never taken a WGSS course before this one and the pedagogy was different from what I was used to. Im glad I was able to expand my academic thinking through the accessible topics of food, identity, and desire.

I learnt how personal food, cooking and eating habits are to people and how invasive we often are of that. I learnt what food means to me and how important of a format for bonding it has become in my life.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: It was a little unclear what we were meant to prepare for the next class so maybe a Canvas announcement would be nice.

strengths: This class is AMAZING. Professor Trumpler does a great job at facilitating discussions and the course content is robust and fascinating. She handles difficult topics extremely well and gives space for every students to express themselves

weaknesses: none!
Love the materials selected for the course.

Strengths: Manageable and engaging workload. Weaknesses: Not a lot of guidance with papers/presentations. I appreciate how open-ended the prompts were, but there was no grading rubric, so I didnt know what kind of writing was expected nor what to include in my papers. I got a lower grade on my first paper and was told I didnt include enough personal reflection (which I didnt know I needed to do). I did more personal reflection in my second paper and got a much higher grade, but it wouldve been nice to know from the start what the professor was looking for (especially since there were only two papers). Ways to improve: Be clearer about writing expectations. Perhaps provide previous essay examples or give students a chance to rewrite their papers?
The strengths were the level of interaction and buy in from all the students. The class was as good as it could have been virtually. I thoroughly enjoyed the readings too!

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Sending ingredients to us to approximate cooking in-person is super cool!

Succeeded: I think overall our zoom seminar worked well and there is not much to change other than being in person

to be improved: we had "kitchen tables" which were small breakout rooms for about 3 people each. I felt very isolated in them because there were so few people and I felt disconnected from the class. Since the class size is small, I wish we could have had more full group discussions or bigger breakout rooms
Very manageable workload!

This course is really built to be in person so you can cook and eat with your classmates, but the prof did an AMAZING job adjusting by having virtual cooking tutorials, sending people supplies so they could cook, and using breakout rooms super effectively.
I believe they all succeeded, it was the most engaging virtual class I have been a part of.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes, absolutely. The readings are fascinating and the themes are so interesting to discuss.

100% YES! If you have a relationship with food (and everyone does) you should take this class. Even if your relationship with food is difficult or hard, this is a safe space to explore that. If your relationship with food is great, this course is a chance to see how food really impacts your life and the lives of people around you. Through this course you will have experiences that you wouldn't have otherwise had (through the interview paper) and you have discussions that really open your eyes to discussions surrounding food. I promise this class will make you a better person and student. 10/10 recommend.
Definitely! It changed my view of food entirely.

A fun and unique class! Even if you've never considered food in an academic context, this course really has something for everyone considering we all eat food every day. The readings were engaging and the class environment felt supportive and low-stakes. I appreciated Prof Trumpler's inclusive vision of the type of content and methods that should count as worthy of academic study.
I would definitely recommend this class! The works you read are super engaging, Professor Trumpler is a star, and the class is super manageable work-load wise.

Maybe? If the intersection of food and identity really interests you, then go for it! The workload is manageable with accessible readings and open-ended papers/presentations. However, I wouldnt say I learned a ton in this course. I mainly just became more aware of other peoples experiences with food and got a couple of insights into the food service industry.

This is the best class I have taken at Yale. I have come out of it more aware, empathetic and intentional with my own relationship to food as well as others. I wish I could take this course every semester. The guest lectures, discussions, readings and assignments were all incredibly useful and furthered my own learning and understanding of the topic.p
